lines.content: This document tracks the use of AI tools during the development of this project.
It records which tools were used, for what purpose, and key observations about their usefulness.
- Helped debug parser logic (`parseCommand` missing `list`/`bye` cases).
- Suggested SLAP-compliant refactors for `UPDATE` command handling.
- Drafted Javadoc comments for several methods (`updateEvent`, `showList`).
- Very effective for spotting missing enum cases and suggesting robust string parsing (`.trim().split("\\s+")`).
- Javadoc generation saved ~15–20 minutes per method.
- SLAP guidance helped keep code clean and modular.
- Sometimes suggestions were overly detailed (needed trimming down).
- Needed manual tweaks to match our coding standards (e.g., constant naming).
- Explained differences between `git revert` and `git reset` when undoing an accidental merge.
- Provided commit message guidelines to avoid standard violations.
- Clear explanations of safe vs destructive Git commands.
- Helpful commit message templates that are easy to follow.
- Some Git commands were Linux-centric; needed small tweaks for macOS environment.
- File will be updated weekly alongside `CONTRIBUTORS.md`.
- Purpose: transparency on AI tool usage, and reflection on effectiveness.
This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/darren_bot.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run darren_bot.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.

- Use Gradle to build and run the application.
This will compile the project and start the application.
- Type a command and press **Enter** (or click **Send**).
- Type `bye` to exit. The window will close after showing the goodbye message.
- You’ll see a welcome banner in the terminal.
> **Indexing:** Commands use **zero-based** indices (the first task is `0`).
Add a task with a due date. Date must be `yyyy-mm-dd`.
Add a task with a start and end (free-form strings).
Mark a task done / not done.
Case-insensitive substring search across task text.
Update the **from** and **to** fields of an event.
If the task at that index is not an event, an error is shown.
- Data file path: **`data/duke.txt`** (created automatically on first run).
- Storage format is a simple pipe-delimited text:
- If the data file is missing or corrupted, the app starts with an **empty list**.

This project maintains **`AI.md`** (in the repo root, next to `CONTRIBUTORS.md`) that records use of AI tools for increments and observations on their usefulness. Please keep it updated periodically (e.g., weekly).

* A launcher class to workaround classpath issues.
* A GUI for DarrenBot using FXML.
private final DarrenBot darrenBot = new DarrenBot();
* Main GUI controller for the DarrenBot application.

*

This class manages the primary user interface of the chatbot. It handles user input,
* displays the conversation as dialog boxes, and interacts with the backend {@link DarrenBot}
* instance to generate responses. The layout is defined via an FXML file, with injected fields
* representing UI components such as the scroll pane, text input, and dialog container.

*

The controller also initializes automatic scrolling of the dialog container
* and binds event handlers to capture and process user interactions.

*
  • Binds the scroll pane to follow new messages dynamically.

*
  • Injects and manages a {@link DarrenBot} instance to produce responses.

*
  • Appends user and bot dialog boxes to the chat container.

*
  • {@code scrollPane} – Scrollable container for the dialog list.

*
  • {@code dialogContainer} – Holds dialog boxes for the conversation.

*
  • {@code userInput} – Text field for entering user commands/messages.

*
  • {@code sendButton} – Button to trigger message submission.

*

Associated images (user and bot avatars) are loaded from the {@code /images} resource folder.
* Creates two dialog boxes, one echoing user input and the other containing Duke's reply and then appends them to
* the dialog container. Clears the user input after processing.
Label helloWorld = new Label("Hello World! This is DarrenBot");
* Utility class that translates raw user input strings into structured commands
* and arguments that the application can understand.

*
  • Identifying the command type (e.g., {@code todo}, {@code deadline}, {@code event}, etc.).
*   <li>Extracting any additional arguments required by that command,
* such as task descriptions, deadlines, or date ranges.

*
  • Throwing {@link EmptyTaskException} when user input is incomplete or invalid.
* Parses a raw line of user input and maps it to a supported {@link Command}.

*                            or if the deadline format is invalid

* Handles reading from and writing to the storage file that persists user tasks.
* The {@code Storage} class is responsible for:

*
  • Ensuring that the data directory and file exist before use.

*
  • Loading saved tasks from the file into memory as a {@link TaskList}.

*
  • Appending new tasks to the file when they are added.

*
  • Rewriting the entire file to reflect updates such as deletes or marks/unmarks.
* Constructs a new {@code Storage} instance pointing to the given file path.
* @param filePath the file path where tasks should be stored and loaded from
* Ensures that the data file exists.
* Creates the parent directories if they do not exist,
* and creates the data file itself if it does not already exist.
* @throws IOException if the directories or file cannot be created

* @throws UnexpectedCommandException if a line in the file does not match a known task type

assertEquals("[E][ ] sleep now (from: today to: tomorrow)", new Event("sleep now", "today", "tomorrow").toString());
assertEquals("[E][ ] sleep later (from: yesterday to: day before)", new Event("sleep later", "yesterday", "day before").toString());
assertEquals("[T][ ] sleep now", new Todo("sleep now").toString());
assertEquals("[T][ ] sleep later", new Todo("sleep later").toString());
